text: well I'm just hugely frustrating our
expectation to the Labour Party not
massively high but they were certainly
higher than this we have in front of us
a set of cuts in the incomes to some of
the poorest but hardest working people
in this country that are unnecessary the
reality is that liberal democrats
absolutely in our timing government and
still now are committed to balancing the
books and clearing the deficit but these
are proposals which are unnecessary and
counterproductive these take thousands
of pounds net from the pockets of some
of the hardest working but porous paid
people in this country it renders young
people in a position where they've got
to choose potentially sometimes
destitution or to be in a place which is
unsafe because of housing benefit cuts
and it threatens especially people who
want to get back to work of mental
health conditions and yet need help
rather than being immediately dumped
into a situation where they will be
potentially made worse all those things
are a thought it was a no-brainer for a
Labour contender even a Blairite labour
contender to want to be able to support
the Liberal Democrats and others who
felt that these proposals were wrong and
I was just I'm just disappointed hugely
in Harrier and three of the four labor
leader can tell David leadership
contenders who chose to sit on their
hands whilst leaving the heavy lifting
the Liberal Democrats I mean there are a
lot of a sizeable number of Labour MPs
who feel exactly as you do and that is
why the story and the party is in the
news today so can you can you draw any
comfort of the fact i mean the lib dems
in that sense or not on their own there
are lots of people who agree with you
know and i think that is the frustrating
thing that opposing these cuts which are
unnecessary we are not at all denying
the need to balance the books to clear
the deficit but you do that by making
sure there's a balance between some
savings and the same time increasing
taxation on those who are the wealthiest
people the thing about this welfare bill
and indeed the budget as a whole is that
it is the balance that is so offensive
really now you take money out the
pockets the hardest working people young
people families other people at the same
time as the considers we want to give a
inheritance tax cut to the six percent
of richest estates in this country
that's just obviously unfair and
necessary and so yes it's great to see
others joining us in the lobby last
night including some labor backbenchers
and indeed one potential labor leader we
shall see but what I am most
disappointed with is the sense that this
is a time and progressives do you need
to be working together to hold a
Conservative Party which has only just
won a general election with a tiny
Monday well a tiny majority and frankly
no mandate and yet we let the Tories off
the hook when the Labour Party act in
such an unbolt and unambitious way I
mean yeah you say I'm bold and
unambitious is this partly a situation
of this is what happens when a party is
without a permanent leader it will have
one in a couple of months from now but
is this perhaps not something almost
inevitable within the political cycle
where a party and your party's just gone
through it is still trying to find its
voice and trying to work out who its
leader should be do you know I am
confident that have this vote been a
week ago and when the Liberal Democrats
didn't have a leader I am confident that
we would all have been voting against
this it seems that no brain like a say
to the layer party to be opposed to this
but the Liberal Democrats will take the
lead if labour will not and so I'm proud
that we did the right thing last night
I'm also proud that we are saying to the
Conservatives that whilst we absolutely
accept the need to balance the books and
to recover and and improve our national
economy and the finances a public
finances need to be put on an even keel
this is a moment or we should be
ambitious and including people who are
from working backgrounds but from poorer
backgrounds and for improving their lot
that means this is a moment was to be
investing in capital infrastructure in
green infrastructure and better
broadband in in better public transport
this is the moment to do just that to
make everybody a bit wealthier and have
some more wealth to redistribute
